p.text: [Pt 45 insrt Amendment 10 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[12], effective 7 July 2006]

entry.emph: Division 1 — Supreme Court specialist lists — Rules 45.1 –45.8

row.entry: This Division deals with the entry of proceedings in the specialist lists of the Supreme Court. Specialist lists for the Common Law Division and the Equity Division of the Supreme Court are specified and described.

entry.emph: Division 2 — District Court specialist lists — Rules 45.9 –45.14

row.entry: This Division deals with the entry of proceedings in the specialist lists of the District Court.
Division 1 only applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court and Div 2 applies to proceedings in the District Court.
The rules in Div 1 of this Part, and the related Sch 8 of the UCPR, are based on the former SCR Pts 14, 14A, 14B, 14C and 14D. The rules in Div 2 are based on the former DCR Pts 24A and 24B.
Certain rules do not apply to a list ‥ [45.7.10]
Certain rules do not apply to Commercial List ‥ [45.6.25]
Discretion to remove a matter from the Commercial list ‥ [45.6.20]
History of the Commercial List and Commercial Division ‥ [45.6.10]
Entry as indicated by originating process ‥ [r 45.1]
Short form of statement of claim ‥ [45.4.10]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 45.1] r 45.1 Entry as indicated by originating process

leg:heading.title: Entry as indicated by originating process

p.text: If the originating process in proceedings in the Common Law Division of the Supreme Court indicates that the proceedings are intended to be entered in one of the following lists, the proceedings are to be entered in that list:
The Administrative Law List
The Defamation List
The Possession List
The Professional Negligence List

If the originating process in proceedings in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court indicates that the proceedings are intended to be entered in one of the following lists, the proceedings are to be entered in that list:
The Admiralty List
The Commercial List
The Technology and Construction List
The Protective List
The Revenue List
The Probate List

[subr (2) subst Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[27], effective 8 December 2006 ; am Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 5 October 2007 ; Amendment 56 of 2012 Sch 1[3], effective 21 January 2013]

If proceedings are commenced by an originating process under the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 , the proceedings are to be entered in the Corporations List in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court.
In this Division, the lists referred to in subrules (1) , (2) and (3) are referred to as specialist lists.
Legislation cited in [45.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 28.

The Chief Justice may designate a list judge to manage particular classes of proceedings specified by the Chief Justice: SCA s 28 . The designated lists and specific procedures that apply to the various specialist lists are summarised in the following table:

Practice Note SC Eq 8 (reproduced at [SC Eq 8] in vol 2) includes the procedures for expedition applications in the Equity Division. The procedure is also discussed in Vaughan v Dawson [2005] NSWSC 33; BC200500479 . The procedure can be summarised as follows:

application is to be made by filing notice of motion returnable before the Expedition Judge and is to be accompanied by an affidavit which proves the matters relied on in the application (“affidavit in support of expedition”);
the affidavit in support of the expedition application should be as short as possible and include:
all factors to be relied upon to establish suitability for expedition;
concise account of the issues likely to be involved in the case;

any other matters which the applicant plans to ask the Expedition Judge to take into account in giving directions or setting down the matter for hearing (eg that a particular judge has heard a related application; that a witness is unavailable for a certain period);
a realistic estimate of how long the case will take (taking into account likely number of witnesses, length of cross-examination, length of addresses;
if the applicant’s solicitor is the deponent of the affidavit, then additional proof of certain matters (eg if the basis of the application is the health of a party or witness); and
any additional documents to be made part of the evidence should be annexed, not exhibited, to the affidavit.

The Expedition Judge hears applications for expedition on Fridays. Practitioners must be in a position to provide an agreed timetable for the preparation of the matter for trial with an accurate estimate of timeframe within which the matter will be ready for trial and an accurate estimate of the necessary hearing time. The matter may lose its expedited status if the parties do not comply with the timetable.
Legislation cited in [45.1.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 Pt II, s 41(4), s 44(1).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 8 Pt 2, r 1.16.

Before 1 January 1989 the Supreme Court derived its civil Admiralty jurisdiction from the Colonial Courts of Admiralty Act 1890 (UK) and the Admiralty Rules 1952 (NSW): see JM Bennett, A History of the Supreme Court of New South Wales (1974) Ch 10; Sir Frederick Jordan, The Admiralty Jurisdiction in New South Wales (1947); McIlwraith McEacharn Ltd v Shell Co of Australia Ltd (1945) 70 CLR 175; [1945] ALR 361 ; Swift & Co Ltd v Ship SS “Heranger” (1965) 82 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 540 at 543 ; Lewmarine Pty Ltd v The Kaptayanni [1974] VR 465 at 467 .

In 1988 the Commonwealth enacted the Admiralty Act 1988. Section 44(1) of that Act effected the repeal of the United Kingdom Act in its application to the Commonwealth of Australia and its Territories. As a consequence of that repeal the 1952 Admiralty Rules lapsed but they were, nevertheless, formally rescinded by Amendment 214 of 23 December 1988. For proceedings commenced after 1 January 1989 Admiralty jurisdiction is conferred on the Supreme Court by Pt II and s 41(4) of the 1988 Commonwealth Act. Admiralty proceedings are assigned to the Equity Division of the court: UCPR r 1.16 and Sch 8 Pt 2 . The Admiralty Act 1988 is set out in Vol 3, “Other Legislation”. The Admiralty Rules made under the Act are also set out in Vol 3. No separate rules have been made for New South Wales — for the reasons set out in para 214 of the Australian Law Reform Commission Report on Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction: ALRC 33. Practice Note SC Eq 2 explains the operation of the Admiralty list.

Practice Note SC Eq 4 explains the operation of the Corporations List and the hearing arrangements for corporations matters. A judge of the Equity Division is assigned to Corporations matters as Corporations Judge on a full-time basis. For contact details see http://www.supremecourt.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/supremecourt/sco2_yai_corporations/sco2_yai_ corporationsjudges.html .

Practice Note SC Eq 9 sets out the case management procedures for the Commercial Arbitration list. UCPR Pt 47 sets out general rules governing applications arising out of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 (NSW).
Practice Note SC Eq 7 sets out the case management procedures for the Family Provision list.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 45.2] r 45.2 Entry and removal of proceedings pursuant to order of Supreme Court

leg:heading.title: Entry and removal of proceedings pursuant to order of Supreme Court

p.text: Proceedings are to be entered in, or removed from, a specialist list if the Supreme Court so orders.

The court has a discretion in making an order for entry in the list where the particular list procedures involve particular expedition, or perhaps where compliance with those procedures would or might unnecessarily increase the costs of proceedings. Delay in making the application for entry may be a factor against such an order being made: TSF Engineering Pty Ltd v Hill [1980] 2 NSWLR 105 ; Allan Robinson Textiles Pty Ltd v Pappas [1983] 1 VR 345 ; Challenge Bank Ltd v Raine & Horne Commercial Pty Ltd (1989) 17 NSWLR 297 at 304.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 45.3] r 45.3 The Administrative Law List (cf SCR Part 14D, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: The Administrative Law List (cf SCR Part 14D, rule 1)

p.text: The following proceedings in the Supreme Court are to be entered in the Administrative Law List:
proceedings for commanding or otherwise requiring a public body or a public officer to perform a public duty,
proceedings for prohibiting or otherwise restraining a public body or a public officer from performing or purporting to perform any act,
proceedings for determining by declaration or otherwise any matter concerning the powers of a public body or a public officer,
proceedings in appeals or applications to the Court in respect of decisions of a public body or a public officer under any enactment specified in the rules for the purposes of this subrule.
In this rule:
means:
a specified tribunal within the meaning of section 48 of the Supreme Court Act 1970, or
the Local Court, or
a magistrate, coroner or assistant coroner, or
any other tribunal, person or body of persons prescribed, or belonging to a class prescribed for the purposes of this definition.
[def am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
means a body of persons, whether corporate or unincorporate, constituted by or under an Act and required to perform or performing public duties, but does not include a prescribed tribunal.

means a person holding or acting in a public office under the Government of the State or an office created by or under an Act and required to perform or performing public duties, but does not include a prescribed tribunal.
The operation of this list is dealt with in Practice Note SC CL 3 .

Directions hearings in the Administrative Law list are listed before a registrar each Tuesday at 9.30 am. The registrar will give directions for the preparation of the case, and deal with any interlocutory matters within the powers of a registrar. When matters are ready for hearing, they will be allocated a hearing date by the Common Law Management Registrar. When the hearing has been expedited it will be referred to the Common Law List Judge to fix a hearing date. Contested motions not within the power of the registrar will be referred to the Administrative Law List Judge who will sit on specified Fridays to deal with those matters. The List Judge will deal with reference to an associate judge of appeals and applications relating to the Consumer Trader Tenancy Tribunal and the Administrative Decisions Tribunal. Those referred matters will thereafter be listed before the registrar in the usual way until allocated a hearing date.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 45.4] r 45.4 The Possession List (cf SCR Part 14B, rules 1 and 2)

leg:heading.title: The Possession List (cf SCR Part 14B, rules 1 and 2)

p.text: Proceedings in the Common Law Division of the Supreme Court in which a claim for possession of land is made are to be entered in the Possession List.
Subrule (1) does not apply to:
proceedings that involve a professional negligence claim, being proceedings entered in the Professional Negligence List, or
proceedings that involve an appeal against, or an application for a stay of, an order made by the Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal under the Residential Tenancies Act 2010.
[subr (2) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[14], effective 6 July 2007; am Amendment 44 of 2011 Sch 1[7], effective 15 April 2011]

A reference to this rule to an order made under the Residential Tenancies Act 2010 is taken to include a reference to an order made under the Residential Tenancies Act 1987 as in force before its repeal.
[subr (3) insrt Amendment 44 of 2011 Sch 1[8], effective 15 April 2011]
The operation of this list is dealt with in Practice Note SC CL 6 .

level.toc-caption: [45.4.10] Short form of statement of claim

p.text: Legislation cited in [45.4.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 14.15.

heading.title: Short form of statement of claim

p.text: Practice Note SC CL 6 provides a short form of statement of claim for use in the case of a claim for possession, or possession and debt, against a defendant who is a borrower/mortgagor: para 6 and Annex 1 to Practice Note SC CL 6. This short form of statement of claim is not prescribed and is not compulsory. It is intended to provide a simplified form of pleading to facilitate an understanding by the defendant of the nature of the claim and the practical consequences which may result. Whether the short form of statement of claim or a conventional form is used it must comply with the requirements as to pleadings in UCPR r 14.15 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 45.5] r 45.5 The Professional Negligence List (cf SCR Part 14C, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: The Professional Negligence List (cf SCR Part 14C, rule 1)

p.text: Proceedings in the Common Law Division of the Supreme Court in which a professional negligence claim is made may be entered in the Professional Negligence List.
[repealed]
[subr (2) rep Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[14], effective 6 July 2007]
The operation of this list is dealt with in Practice Note SC CL 7 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 45.6] r 45.6 The Commercial List (cf SCR Part 14, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: The Commercial List (cf SCR Part 14, rule 1)

p.text: The following proceedings in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court may be entered in the Commercial List:
proceedings arising out of commercial transactions,
proceedings in which there is an issue that has importance in trade or commerce.
In this rule, issue includes any question or issue in any proceedings, whether of fact or law or partly of fact and partly of law, and whether raised by pleadings, agreement of parties or otherwise.

The operation of this list is dealt with in Practice Note SC Eq 3 . The provisions of the Practice Note SC Eq 3 require the initiating process to be accompanied by a Commercial List Statement containing the information provided for in para 8 of SC Eq 3 .

level.toc-caption: [45.6.10] History of the Commercial List and Commercial Division

heading.title: History of the Commercial List and Commercial Division

p.text: The Supreme Court Act and the rules (previously in the SCR and now in the UCPR) have, long made special provision for the expeditious conduct of commercial matters. Originally, the commercial list was part of the Common Law Division. In 1985 the Supreme Court (Commercial Division) Amendment Act created the Commercial Division of the Court. In 1998, the rules were amended to transfer the business of the Commercial Division to the Equity Division.

There is a short informative account of the history of the procedures relating to commercial matters in the judgment of Rogers CJ Comm Div in Challenge Bank Ltd v Raine & Horne Commercial Pty Ltd (1989) 17 NSWLR 297 at 299–305 . For a more detailed understanding reference could be made to A Colman and V Lyon, The Practice and Procedure of the Commercial Court 4th ed, Lloyd of London Press, 1995.

The description of the proceedings assigned by the rule does not lend itself readily to precise definition. However, it repeats the substance of the criteria that have previously been applied to the Commercial Division and (before that) to the Commercial List referred to in the former s 56 of the Supreme Court Act 1970. No doubt the following principles developed in relation to the former provisions will continue to be of relevance: Challenge Bank Ltd v Raine & Horne Commercial Pty Ltd, above.

In deciding whether proceedings may be entered in the Commercial List the critical matters are the nature of the issues involved and whether they arise out of an ordinary commercial transaction: Malleys Ltd v Horton Investments Ltd (1961) 78 WN (NSW) 1128 and see Smith v Jamieson (1958) 75 WN (NSW) 427 and Bilfield v Herman (1960) 78 WN (NSW) 628 . Mere convenience cannot give jurisdiction to allow entry: FTS O'Donnell & Co Ltd v Celebrity Circuit Ltd (1957) 74 WN (NSW) 490 . See also NRMA Insurance Ltd v Flanagan [1982] 1 NSWLR 585 where all the relevant authorities are discussed and also Challenge Bank Ltd v Raine & Horne Commercial Pty Ltd (1989) 17 NSWLR 297 at 307.

Neither party need be a merchant or trader (Malleys Ltd v Horton Investments Ltd (1961) 78 WN (NSW) 1128 , not following Trubenised Ltd v Dobrinski (1957) 74 WN (NSW) 492 on this point); nor need the transaction be common or usual for the parties (Malleys Ltd v Horton Investments Ltd, above; Gilbert's (Aust) Agency (Vic) Pty Ltd v Peko Mines NL (1958) 75 WN (NSW) 440 ); or usual in the trade: Trubenised Ltd v Dobrinski, above. There must be a commercial element but it need not be between the parties: Farmer & Co Ltd v Moss (1952) 69 WN (NSW) 324 .

Proceedings may be entered in the Commercial List, even if they are formulated as a claim in conversion, where the plaintiff's title to the goods depends upon the construction of shipping documents: Farmer & Co Ltd v Moss, above. Proceedings for negligence in relation to the supply of industrial plant may be entered: Electrolytic & Smelting Co of Australia Ltd v Commonwealth Industrial Gases Ltd [1972]1 NSWLR 257. The inclusion of a charge of fraud against a stranger to the proceedings will not preclude entry: Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia v Galong Pty Ltd (1957) 75 WN (NSW) 126 . Proceedings may be entered in the list on the basis of the eligibility of only one of alternative claims: Delfino v Trevis (No 2) [1963] NSWR 194 . This is so even if there is a cross-claim that could not be entered: Trubenised Ltd v Dobrinski (1957) 74 WN (NSW) 492 . Proceedings relating to the sale of shares in a trading enterprise may be eligible for entry in the list: Malleys Ltd v Horton Investments Ltd (1961) 78 WN (NSW) 1128 .

Proceedings on a foreign judgment may not be entered even if the judgment arises out of a commercial transaction: Delfino v Trevis (No 2) [1963] NSWR 194 . Nor are proceedings relating to retail transactions generally regarded as appropriate for entry: United Development Corp Ltd v Coffs Harbour Rutile NL (1957) 75 WN (NSW) 218 and FTS O'Donnell & Co Ltd v Celebrity Circuit Ltd (1957) 74 WN (NSW) 490 ; but see Dumas Hotels Pty Ltd v York Motors (Sales) Pty Ltd [1970] 1 NSWR 115 in which proceedings relating to warranties upon a retail sale of goods were entered. Proceedings relating to the services of a ship owner or carrier may be entered but not proceedings relating to professional or unskilled services (United Development Corp Ltd v Coffs Harbour Rutile NL, above), nor the services of electrical contractors (FTS O'Donnell & Co Ltd v Celebrity Circuit Ltd, above), nor proceedings relating to a contract for the supply of professional entertainers: Gastel v Smith [1968] 1 NSWR 361 . However an action for damages for professional negligence could be entered in the commercial list whenever the real issue arising for determination in the proceedings could be described as arising from “an ordinary commercial transaction”. Accordingly actions against accountants (TSF Engineering Pty Ltd v Hill [1980] 2 NSWLR 105 ); and solicitors could be entered in the list: Galong Investments Pty Ltd v Biddulph [1980] 2 NSWLR 677 . See generally Poforo Pty Ltd v Allman [1984] 3 NSWLR 429 and contrast Sextus Pty Ltd v McMillan [1985] VR 81 where it was held that a professional negligence claim was not a proceeding arising from an “ordinary commercial transaction”.

A jury may be permitted in a commercial cause where fraud is involved, but the complexity of the matter may indicate that it would be more satisfactory for trial without a jury: Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia v Galong Pty Ltd (1957) 75 WN (NSW) 126 ; Water Lily Sales Pty Ltd v New Zealand Insurance Co Ltd [1976] 2 NSWLR 402 .

Applications to be entered in the commercial list must be made promptly and not after the parties have elected the ordinary procedure: Retravision (NSW) Ltd v Threlfo (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 189; TSF Engineering Pty Ltd v Hill [1980] 2 NSWLR 105 .

level.toc-caption: [45.6.20] Discretion to remove a matter from the Commercial list

p.text: Legislation cited in [45.6.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 45.6(1)(a).
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 54.

heading.title: Discretion to remove a matter from the Commercial list

p.text: One of the functions of the Commercial List is to provide for the prompt and expert resolution of proceedings that raise issues of commercial significance beyond the interests of the immediate parties. However, r 45.6(1)(a) permits any proceedings “arising out of commercial transactions” to be entered in the Commercial List. The width of that expression includes many proceedings that involve no more that the application of settled principles to the circumstances of the particular case. The business of the Commercial List, therefore, involves some tension between, on the one hand, its ability to carry out its specialist function and, on the other, its practical ability to provide for the prompt determination of all proceedings arising out of commercial transactions. Accordingly, the court has a discretion to remove proceedings from the List notwithstanding that they do arise out of commercial transactions: Challenge Bank Ltd v Raine & Horne Commercial Pty Ltd (1989) 17 NSWLR 297 ; Mortgage Acceptance Nominees Ltd v Beatty (NSWCA, Kirby P, Mahoney, Handley JJA, 9 August 1991, unreported, BC9101687); Collins v Mead (NSWSC, Rogers CJ Comm Div, 7 March 1990, unreported, BC9002671); Dalgety Farmers Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp (NSWSC, Rogers CJ Comm Div, 19 October 1990, unreported, BC9001844) (foreign currency loan cases). See also SCA s 54 which provides a discretion to transfer proceedings from one division of the court to another.
The court will consider the following matters when determining whether to allow proceedings to remain in the commercial list or to transfer proceedings into the commercial list:

whether the issues require the Commercial List's special procedures or expertise (Challenge Bank Ltd v Raine & Horne Commercial Pty Ltd, above); Coastline Constructions (Aust) Pty Ltd v Kakavas [2008] NSWSC 388; BC200802983 at [18] (commercial aspects not complex — proposed cross-claim for assault — transfer from Common Law Division refused);

whether the conduct of the parties has or will permit the court to determine the matter expeditiously (NRMA Insurance Ltd v Flanagan [1982] 1 NSWLR 585 at 597–9 ; TSF Engineering Pty Ltd v Hill [1980] 2 NSWLR 105 at 110 );
the estimated length of the hearing: Poforo Pty Ltd v Allman [1984] 3 NSWLR 429 at 433 .

whether the proceedings were properly commenced in another division and the ability of that division to appropriately and expeditiously manage the proceedings: Coastline Constructions (Aust) Pty Ltd v Kakavas [2008] NSWSC 388; BC200802983 at [18] .

level.toc-caption: [45.6.25] Certain rules do not apply to Commercial List

p.text: Legislation cited in [45.6.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 46 Div 2, r 31.10, r 46.10, r 50.11, r 50.4, r 50.9.

heading.title: Certain rules do not apply to Commercial List

p.text: A number of rules in the UCPR are specified not to apply to proceedings enterred in the Commercial List. See:
r 31.10 Opportunity to inspect plans, photographs and models;
r 46.10 Accounts and Inquiries in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court under Pt 46 Div 2 ;
r 50.4 Summons commencing an appeal must state the ground of appeal;
r 50.9 Appeal must not be heard within 21 days of service of summons;
r 50.11 Notice of contention.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 45.7] r 45.7 The Technology and Construction List (cf SCR Part 14A, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: The Technology and Construction List (cf SCR Part 14A, rule 1)

p.text: The following proceedings in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court may be entered in the Technology and Construction List:
proceedings relating to or arising out of:
the design, carrying out, supervision or inspection of any building or engineering work, or
the performance by any building or engineering expert of any other services with respect to any building or engineering work, or
any certificate, advice or information given or withheld with respect to any building or engineering work, or
the Building and Construction Industry Security of Payment Act 1999 ,

proceedings relating to or arising out of, or the determination of which involves, the design, acquisition, disposal or operation of technology in commercial transactions or in transactions involving Government,
proceedings on a claim for rectification, setting aside or cancellation of any agreement with respect to matters mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b) .
In this rule:
includes a builder, engineer, architect, designer and quantity surveyor.
includes:
any intended building or engineering work, and
any building or engineering work in the course of construction or completion or which has been substantially or fully completed, and
any associated work.
This List is administered by the judges of the Equity Division. The operation of this list is dealt with in Practice Note SC Eq 3 (reproduced at [SC Eq 3] in vol 2).

level.toc-caption: [45.7.10] Certain rules do not apply to a list

p.text: Legislation cited in [45.7.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 46 Div 2, r 31.10, r 46.10.

heading.title: Certain rules do not apply to a list

p.text: A number of rules in the UCPR are specified not to apply to proceedings enterred in the Technology and Construction List. See:
r 31.10 Opportunity to inspect plans, photographs and models;
r 46.10 Accounts and Inquiries in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court under Pt 46 Div 2 .
The following proceedings in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court may be entered in the Revenue List:
proceedings in which:
the Commissioner of Taxation, or a Second Commissioner of Taxation or Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, in and for the Commonwealth, or
the holder of an equivalent office in and for a jurisdiction outside Australia,
is a party,
proceedings in which:
the Chief Commissioner of State Revenue, or the Commissioner of State Revenue, in and for New South Wales, or
the holder of an equivalent office in and for a jurisdiction outside New South Wales,
is a party,
proceedings in which an issue has arisen in relation to a law under which the holder of an office referred to in paragraph (a) or (b) exercises functions.
[r 45.7A insrt Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[28], effective 8 December 2006 ; am Amendment 13 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[11], effective 5 April 2007]
The operation of this list is dealt with in Practice Note SC Eq 10. A template summons for Chief Commissioner proceedings is provided in Annexure A to this Practice Note.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 45.8] r 45.8 Proceedings under particular Acts and instruments (cf SCR Part 12, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Proceedings under particular Acts and instruments (cf SCR Part 12, rule 1)

p.text: Proceedings in the Supreme Court:
under an Act or instrument referred to in Column 1 of Part 1 or 2 of Schedule 8, or
under a provision referred to in Column 2 of that Part in respect of any such Act or instrument,
are to be entered in the list (if any) referred to in Column 4 of that Part in respect of that Act, instrument or provision.
